title: What Happened to Curiosity? (Part 1)

victoriaExcalidrawCuration.setup: Created multi-user Excalidraw board with hand-drawn aesthetic
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.snapshot: Took copy of board state so 'if everything is messed, it doesn't matter'
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.caution: In email thread, given many solutions closing the problem very early - not what we should strive for
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.approach: Instead of 'Education closes curiosity', state as question: 'Does education close curiosity?' - opens more things to work with
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.jerryClarification: Positing multiple theories instead of choosing one to close it down
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.victoriaGoal: Gather all opinions but show we are not closing, but opening
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.ongoingTheme: Like when I first talked to Jerry and he said trust and consumerism were his things, I understood curiosity has been always a concern for me
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.linking: Issue of access links to books as 'fossil knowledge' (trapped), silos, academia paid subscriptions - a lot of things going on
victoriaExcalidrawCuration.proposal: Gather everything and start thinking how this relates to different OGM projects, or different things that can start from here

kevinDisagreement.premise: Is the premise that we are losing, or curiosity is being diminished?
kevinDisagreement.position: If that's it, I completely disagree

selectionBias.originalQuestion: Hey, kids in school seem incurious
selectionBias.generalAgreement: In general, the room will agree with Kevin: no, no, no
selectionBias.bias: We have a selection bias problem - everybody in this room is really, really curious, and probably hangs out with really curious people

bigFiveOpenness.model: Big Five personality model - statistically verified
bigFiveOpenness.fiveDimensions: Openness is one of the five
bigFiveOpenness.openness: People who tend to be creative, interested in intellectual pursuits, open to new things and new ways, curious
bigFiveOpenness.spectrum: Exists on a spectrum - there are people who are low in openness
bigFiveOpenness.evolutionaryNeutrality: Neither end of the spectrum is evolutionarily better, which is why we have the spectrum
bigFiveOpenness.lowOpennessValue: Sometimes you need to be less open and more literal, practical, tradition, history, ritual
bigFiveOpenness.highOpennessValue: Sometimes you need to be more open, accepting, combining, far-reaching
bigFiveOpenness.ogmBias: This group tends to be high in openness - room attracts those kinds of people
bigFiveOpenness.observation: If looking for evidence of less curious, we're going to continue to notice instances where people are less curious (those less on the open side)
bigFiveOpenness.scottsView: Haven't seen a sea change in that - believe it exists on a range

gilOneWayConversations.initialAssessment: People much younger than me were not curious
gilOneWayConversations.evidence: Conversations where I would ask them questions, and they would not ask me questions - perplexing
gilOneWayConversations.networkingSituations: Meeting somebody at conference - really struck at how one-way those conversations have been
gilOneWayConversations.newStrategy: Taken recently to start talking about things - what I'm up to, doing, want to talk about, would have wanted to be asked about
gilOneWayConversations.result: Then conversation proceeds normally, interested, back and forth - but initiation, asking questions about somebody else, noticing it in its absence

personalExample.person: Woman they've known since she was 12, now ~55
personalExample.occasion: Dinner few months ago, spent 3 hours together, lovely buffet, backyard
personalExample.observation: Didn't ask a single question of us - not 'How are you doing? How's your life? How's your health?'
personalExample.context: Knows Jane has been going through major health issues for many years
personalExample.gilReaction: Became increasingly uncomfortable, really baffled, didn't figure out what was weird until afterwards, never been in situation like that
personalExample.significance: Challenges my assumption that it's a phenomenon of younger people - she's not young

gilOneWayConversations.oldDataPoint: Early on in Natural Logic, doing site assessments of companies looking at efficiency...

excalidrawThemes.approach: Hand-drawn aesthetic, multi-user, questions rather than answers

excalidrawThemes.method: Open questions to generate possibilities, not close down with solutions

emergingQuestions: Are we losing curiosity or is it being diminished?
Why do some people not ask questions in conversations?
Is lack of curiosity a generational phenomenon or personality trait?
How does the Big Five Openness dimension relate to curiosity?
What is the relationship between access to knowledge and curiosity?
How do silos and paywalls affect curiosity?
What is 'fossil knowledge' and how does it trap information?
